Icon Creation Guidelines

Details on how to create an ADAPT icon.

Icons and the ADAPT Icon Font

Icons and images are critical to the overall user experience. They convey meaning that help the user navigate the contents of products and find information quickly. BMC products use an icon font instead of PNG or SVG icons. The ADAPT icon font includes system icons and a small group of product icons. System icons, or UI icons, symbolize a command, file, device, or directory. System icons are also used to represent common actions like trash, print, and save. Product icons are the visual expression of a brand’s products, services and tools. There are also a lot of icons that represent specific functions or objects.

Templates for creating icons are available here:

How to create a perfect icon aligned to BMC products? Things to know

The designer should take a few steps before creating the perfect icon aligned to BMC products.

  1. Determine the name and/or description of the future icon. This will help in searching for all possible meanings and visual associations. For example a resource server icon: “server, resource, settings, manufacturing…”
  2. Search for the most common visual associations. The gear is the most common visual representation for these resources…
  3. Using the Icon Finder, search through what we already have in the ADAPT font.
    The ADAPT icon font already contains a server and a gear icon. The server icon represents a server. As a single icon the gear represents settings or manufacturing.  Also the gear used as part of another mechanism can be a symbol for resources.
    Server and gear icons can be parts for a new resource server icon.

    + =

The Icon Grid

Use a simple 1 pixel grid in Adobe Illustrator (the main program for creating icons in the BMC UX team) for creating icons.

The grid is already turned on in the Illustrator template (Illustrator -> View -> Show/Hide Grid). Be sure to turn on guides  (Illustrator -> View -> Guides -> Show/Hide Guides) and make the existing guides layer visible (in the Layers window).


Guides Layer visibility off Guides Layer visibility on 800% scale (192x192px)

Sizes and Shapes

An icon should be created in an artboard sized to 24x24 pixels. This is important in order to achieve consistency across the icons.  When creating icons, it’s also important to design at 100% scale for pixel-perfect accuracy.

100% Scale

800% Scale


Icons from the DPL/ADAPT icon font use geometric shapes to visually represent core ideas, capabilities, or topics. Primary shapes are the square and the circle. A vertical rectangle, horizontal rectangle and a triangle are considered derivative forms.  Icons use the square artboard as a base. All other forms that comprise the icon are contained within this square.  

The size for a primary circle is 24x24 pixels. The size for a primary square is 22x22 pixels.

* A 24x24 pixel square will appear slightly larger than a 24x24 pixel circle; therefore, adjusting the primary square to 22x22 pixels is required in order to visually align the primary shapes. This effect was described in the Gestalt psychology (Gestaltism). Gestalt psychology tries to understand the laws of our ability to acquire and maintain meaningful perceptions in an apparently chaotic world. The central principle of gestalt psychology is that the mind forms a global whole with self-organizing tendencies.

How to Choose Shapes

Circle

All circle forms are 24x24 pixels.

Square

The main size for large squares is 22x22 pixels.

Use 14x14 pixels for the square if an icon should be smaller than all the others in one line.

Large Rectangles

20x24 pixels, 16x24 pixels, 8.5x14 pixels and 6x10 pixels are for vertical rectangles.
24x20 pixels, 24x18 pixels, 24x16 pixels, 24x14 pixels, 14x8.5 pixels and 10x6 pixels are for the horizontal rectangles.
The designer is able to use any of these sizes, whichever offers the most aesthetically pleasing and natural appearance for the icon.

For example, the File icon is 20x24 pixels, whereas the Database icon is 16x24 pixels.

Choosing other rectangle sizes causes causes the icons to appear forced and not optimal.

Small Rectangles

Small rectangles have sizes smaller than 14 px in different dimensions.
8.5x14 pixels and 6x10 pixels are for the vertical rectangles.
14x8.5 pixels and 10x6 pixels are for the horizontal rectangles.button

Triangles

The main sizes for triangles are 24x22 pixels and 22x24 pixels.
22x22 pixels is a size for triangles that helps it to display harmoniously with the other primary shapes.*
* The same rule applies for circles and squares as well.

Using a Square or a Rectangle

The choice between a square or a rectangle depends upon the concept or product being communicated in the icon.
For example, the Server icon uses a vertical rectangle (18x24 pixels). Could a square shape have been used?

By looking at the product itself, it is quickly apparent the rectangle is a more natural base shape for an icon  representing this object.

Combined Icons

When an icon consists of two shapes the smaller one should be 14x14 pixels.

In the following example the artboard is 24x24 pixels. The bigger shape (an app) is 24x20 pixels and aligns top.  The smaller shape (a checkmark in a circle) is 14x14 pixels and aligns bottom and right.

The stroke arround the smaller shape is 2 pixels. In this example the smaller shape is a circle and it is 14x14 pixels.  The circle including its stroke is 18x18 pixels - 2 pixels from every side of the smaller shape.

Stroke and Padding

All strokes are multiples of 2 pixels.*

There may be exceptions. A corner radius could be 1.5 px. For example:

The file in the printer icon is smaller than the original file icon. In this case the corner radius is smaller.

Corners

Consistent corner radiuses are key to unifying the overall system icon family. A 2 px corner radius is used on the silhouette form of the icon. The same is for the corners of strokes (shapes 2 px wide or less).

Interior corners should be square. Do not round the corners of interior shapes.
